Occupation, educational background, family responsibilities. 5. If Quaker, Monthly Meeting member attender 6. How did you hear about the Lyman Fund?"|"Deadlines: Applications and letters of reference must be received by April 1 or October 1. The board"|"While this Clearness Process is a Quaker process, it may be undertaken by another spiritual organization to help a member to discern the right way forward. 1. The applicant invites several (three is a good number) people from his or her meeting, church, temple, sacred circle or other spiritual home to sit in worship, focusing on the applicant's project or educational program for which the applicant is seeking a grant. Plan two to three hours. 2. Applicant sends each participant a written"|"20000.0000"|""|"meets in April and October for funding decisions., background paper in advance of the meeting. 3. Applicant appoints clerk to run the meeting and recording clerk to take notes. 4. Meeting opens with 5 to 20 minutes of silence in which everyone can settle down and inwardly place this meeting under divine care. Someone may choose to offer an opening spoken prayer. 5. The applicant presents background information (repeating aloud what was in the written background paper) and proposal to be made to the Lyman Fund. 6. Participants do not judge or advise, but simply ask questions... deep questions which may help the applicant become ""clear."" Focus person answers the questions. 7. When the questions are answered, there is a second period of silence, followed by each participant saying what he or she heard the applicant say. Clerk notes whether there is a sense that this project or educational program is a true spiritual leading or calling and whether this is the next step on the applicant's spiritual journey. If the focus person and the participants affirm this, one of the participants writes a letter of reference to be placed in a sealed envelope and to be included with the application."|""

Only one proposal may be submitted it a time. If a great is no made, organizations may reapply after one year from the date of decision on a previous proposal. Grants are normally made for one year only."|"418000.0000"|""|"4. A clear and comprehensive description of the project, and an explanation of its significance to the Greater Boston tree. Proposals not containing all of the above information will not be considered. Funds not spent for the specific purpose for which the grant was made must be returned to the trust or foundation and cannot be diverted to other uses without the expressed approval of the Distribution Committee. When the circumstances justify it, however, a commitment may be made for support of a project for two or more years. Click thelink below, but don't forget the access code ""clipper"" after you register. Submit a proposal by going to the online grant application page: www.grantinterface.com/grna/Common/LogOn.aspx Register. Prior to"|"Most Recent Fiscal Year Audit or 990 Required February 10, 2011 October 31, 2011 through November 30"|"Individual CDC-sporisored low income housing development initiatives (the Foundation typically provides CDC support through grants to LISC) Legal Services, Programs whose central focus is advocacy, Religion, Hospitals, Higher Education, Research, Scholarships, Fellowships, Student loans or travel; Writing or publishing of books or articles; Campaigns for endowment funds; Production of mass media; or Expenses related to conferences or conventions."|"1620440.0000"|"45000.0000"|"submitting a proposal through the foundation's online grants system, applicants must complete a one-time registration. Previously registered applicants may simply log-in. You will need to supply your contact information and create a password to log in to the system. The Foundation prefers that the Executive Director register as the main contact. Be sure to save your password where you can find it again because you will need it to work on proposal drafts and check the status of your proposal. If you are a grant writer, please register using the name and email address of the primary contact at theorganization which is applying. If you use your own information, the organization information will be linked to your email address, which will cause a problem if you then try to fillout an application for another client or if you move on and the organization wishes to re-apply or submit a report. Start New Application. Once you are in the system, click Apply on the top left side of your screen. The link to begin the application will not appear until you enter the Access Code Enter Access Code. Enter the code: clipper (all lowercase) in the Access Code box on the middle left side of your screen. Click Link to Open Form. Click the link to the Clipper Ship Foundation to open the Proposal Form. Click on Print Question Legend above your name to get a list of the proposal questions. Draft Application. Complete your on-line application. Save frequently."|""

The poultry industry has rendered great service to the health and well-being of people all over the world. It has led the way in utilizing new knowledge and technology to greatly improve the availability and efficiency of production of animal protein foods for human diets. The Foundation wishes to encourage continued progress in technology and efficiency of production of poultry products. For this purpose, scholar-ships will be made available to support needy and capable students in their pursuit of advanced scientific knowledge in the fields of poultry science, genetics and other life science disciplines at universities that our Trustees consider leaders in these fields of knowledge. 5. "04-2767462"|"FRANK M. BARNARD FOUNDATION, INC."|"935963"|""|"ELEANOR W. ANGOFF"|"PO BOX 2623"|"NEW LONDON"|"NH"|"USA"|"03257"|"603-526-7446"|"1. Background The Frank M. Barnard Foundation is a small charitable foundation established by the late Frank M. Barnard, a master bookbinder whose businesses were concerned primarily with the conservation of library materials-more particularly library books, periodicals and text books. While the scope of the Foundation's grant giving authority is broad, preference is given to libraries and book-related projects. 2. Purposes The purposes of the Frank M. Barnard Foundation are to devote and apply"|"PROPOSALS ARE ACCEPTED FROM JANUARY 1 THROUGH MARCH 31"|""|"38300.0000"|"0.0000"|"its income exdlusively for charitable, religious, scientific, literary or educational purposes, either directly of by contributions to individuals and organizations duly authorized and permitted by law to carry on such activities. No part of the Foundation's funds may inure to the benefit of any private individual, and no part of the direct or indirect activities of the Foundation may consist of carrying on propaganda or otherwise attempting to infulence legislation or of participating in political campaigns. The Foundation shall not conduct activities which are prohibited for charitable, tax-exempt organizations under the applicable laws of the United States of America or the Commonwealth of Massachusetts as they now exist or may from time to time be amended. 3. Grants The Frank M. Barnard Foundation prefers to fund projects that will address a specific problem rather than to meet routine needs which should be supported by regular operating budget procedures of the applicant organizations. Grants are made from income and normally do not exceed $5,000 in any one year, but in an unusual situation, a grant may be extended for longer than one year. Preference is given to challenge or matching grants. Eligible recipients must be tax-exempt organizations under applicable provisions of the United States Internal Revenue Code. 4. Basic Policies (1) The Frank M. Barnard Foundation and its activities are non-commercial, non-sectarian and non-partisan."|""

An organization must have been determined tax-exempt under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and received a permanent or advance I.R.S. Determination Letter that describes the agency as a publicly supported charity as defined in Sections 170(b)(1)(A)(6) or"|"1051400.0000"|"503850.0000"|"2. The Associated Grant Makers of Massachusetts' Common Proposal format is accepted and welcomed by the Trustees. 3. The body of the proposal should be no more than five pages plus appendices. A one-page cover letter, summarizing the proposal and with a request for a specific grant amount should also be included. 4. The proposal will not be considered if the following is missing and has not been previously supplied: a) Copy of I.R.S Determination Letter b) Proof of Incorporation in Massachusetts c) Names of Officers, Directors or Trustees of the organization 5. A complete proposal should include: a. Most recent annual financial statement (preferably audited) b. Institutional Income & Expense budget for current fiscal year c. Detailed program budget for which support is being requested d. Starting & completion dates of proposed program and planned cash flow. 6. If an organization's proposal is complete and fits within the guidelines of The Stevens Foundations, the Director or other officer of that organization may be contacted to provide further details or information. Please include the name, address and telephone number of whom you wish contacted. 7. The Trustees of The Stevens Foundations generally meet monthly, with the exceptions of July and August. While awaiting a decision from The Stevens Foundations, applicants are encouraged to seek other sources of funding., (a)(6). 3. No grants to individuals."|""

a strong commitment to moral and ethical principles of Judaism and concern for the Jewish people throughout the world Over the ensuing twenty-five years, the interest in Jewish causes has continued and the concerns have gone beyond to include other minorities At the time of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Foundation, the Board has taken upon itself the task of redefining its goals so that there is a clear"|""|""|"137350.0000"|""|"sense of mission for the present trustees of the Board and for those that will follow in their place The intent of this task of redefinition is to build on the original purpose of its founder and on the main thrust of the Foundation' grant support during the past twenty-five years It is the belief of the Board that the broad statement below leaves sufficient room for carring on effectively the charitable activities of the Foundation, and it is its its mtent that neither this board or its successors go beyond it Mission and Goats The Jaffe Foundation is dedicated to the support of disadvantaged peoples in the United States and other parts of the world In pursuing these goals, it focuses its support mainly in the areas of health, education, and the arts In addition, it is committed to the survival of the jewish people as a cultural unity and is interested in encouraging the contribution of the jewish people to society at lartge The Foundation will consider proposals in support of a institutions for the performing arts and the fine arts b health care institutions, particularly those that emphasize preventive care c educational institutions where these institutions reach out to the community at large We will also consider proposals from organizations concerned with human rights The Foundation pursues its mission by contributing to non-profit organizations and institutions, which develop programs consistent with the abovd stated goals"|""

THE BUECHEL PATIENT CARE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION FUND WAS"|"85357.0000"|""|"FOUNDED IN 2002 AS A MEANS OF FURTHERING ONGOING PATIENT CARE, RESEARCH AND EDUCATION EFFORTS IN THE FIELD OF ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY AND BIOMEDICAL ENGINEERING. IN ADDITION, THE FUND WAS ESTABLISHED TO SERVE AS A SOURCE OF ASSISTANCE FOR PATIENTS AND STUDENTS WITH SPECIAL NEEDS TO IMPROVE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE. THE FUND SUPPORTS MEDICAL INSTITUTIONS, SCHOOLS AND UNIVERSITIES, PROVIDING FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH, SCHOLARSHIPS AND PATIENT CARE. WHILE THE FUND HAS A SPECIAL INTEREST IN ORTHOPAEDICS, PROPOSALS INVOLVING OTHER MEDICAL SPECIALTIES AND ALL AREAS OF EDUCATION ARE CONSIDERED. ADDITIONALLY, THE FUND ASSISTS NEEDY PATIENTS WITH CATASTROPHIC MEDICAL INJURIES AND CONDITIONS THAT REQUIRE ACCESS TO QUALITY MEDICAL AND REHABILITATION SERVICES. ALL PATIENT CARE GRANTS ARE CHANNELED THROUGH THE TREATING PHYSICIAN OR INSTITUTION AND ARE NOT DISBURSED DIRECTLY TO AN INDIVIDUAL PATIENT. WHILE THE FOUNDATION IS NATIONAL IN SCOPE, THE PRIMARY SERVICE AREAS ARE NEW JERSEY AND FLORIDA."|""

"04-6869254"|"ESTHER B. KAHN CHARITABLE FOUNDATION"|"1013727"|""|"ESTHER B. KAHN CHARITABLE FOUNDATION"|"c/o Choate Hall & Stewart LLP, Two International Place"|"Boston"|"MA"|"USA"|"02110"|""|"8. How do I submit an application? 1. What are your deadlines for receipt of proposals? Proposals are considered semi-annually. Deadline for submission are June 30 and December 30. 2. Does the Foundation make grants to individuals or private foundations? No, the Foundation does not make grants to individuals or organizations classified as a private foundation. The Foundation only makes grants to organizations as described in Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 3. What is the average"|"December 30, 2012"|"What ill be accomplished? Does it have a reasonable assurance of success? Where appropriate, please give a brief description of the scientific rationate. How does it seek to ""break new ground""? Provide a breakdown of its cost. How much of that is ""Overhead""?"|"166000.0000"|"0.0000"|"size and duration of grants awarded? Grants are awarded semi-annually and are one-time cash awards of varying amounts, generally less than $25,000.00. 4. How many grants do you award each year? In 2007, EBK awarded 20 one-time grants. 5. What are the chances that my proposal will receive support? The Foundation receives a large numbers of applications each year and funds those that support the goals and objectives of its patron, Esther B. Kahn, and will make a significant difference with lasting tangible results. 6. Do you have formal application forms? Yes, the Foundation has implemented a two-stage application process to review proposals. Please review ""Application Instructions"" for additional details. How long does it take for a proposal to be approved? The Trustees meet semi-annually, generally in February and August. All applicants will be notified of the Trustee's decision within 10 business days after the meeting. 8. How do I submit an application? There is a two-stage application process to review proposals: a preliminary application and final application (by invitation only). Please review ""Application Instructions"" for additional details."|""

"01-0535144"|"Maine Health Access Foundation, Inc."|"1074847"|""|"Catherine Luce"|"150 Capitol Street, Suite 4"|"Augusta"|"ME"|"USA"|"04330"|"207-620-8266"|"In 2010, the foundation initiated a comprehensive nine-month strategic planning process to guide MeHAF's grant and program activities for the next five years (2011-2016). This planning process included engaging the services of consultants with national philanthropic strategic planning expertise who conducted internal and external stakeholder interviews, environmental assessments that evaluated the demographic, social and economic landscape of Maine, and research of best practices and innovative"|"All submission deadlines are outlined in the Foundation's requests for proposals available through"|"MeHAF generally limits its grant awards offered through competitive RFPs to 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charitable organizations, educational institutions, governmental entities or other public, non-profit entities. Private foundations, individuals, fiscal sponsorships and organizations with pending non-profit status are generally ineligible to receive funding through the competitive RFP process. MeHAF primarily funds Maine-based organizations; however, qualified organizations from outside the state"|"3042348.0000"|"1535294.0000"|"program approaches advanced by both public and private organizations in Maine and across the nation. All this information guided the development of specific program strategies for MeHAF moving forward. The strategic planning process concluded in April 2011 with Board approval of four new strategic priorities that will serve as the focus for our major grant and program funding over the next five years. This work will build on a solid foundation of current innovative, evidence based practices with the aim of spreading rapid adoption and implementation of successful models that can expand access, improve quality, contain costs, and bridge the divide between clinical settings and communities where people live, work and play. Executing the specific program goals for each priority will require long term partnerships with our grantees, other key stakeholders and people in Maine communities we're committed to serve, and may necessitate additional staff resources with new expertise to be successful. MeHAF's four new strategic priorities are listed on our website at www.mehaf.org. MeHAF provides explicit guidance for the submission of grant applications on its webiste. Current information about MeHAF's grant programs is available at www.mehaf.org under the section marked ""Grants."" In 2011, MeHAF issued several Request for Propsals (RFP) for the strategic priorities: Strengthening Maine's Safety Net; Promoting Patient & Family Centered Care; and Advancing Health Reform."|""

Cabot, the Cabot Family Charitable Trust makes grant awards in arts and culture, education and youth development, environment and conservation, health and human services, and civic and public benefit. Within these fields, as appropriate, the trustees have a special interest in programs focused on insuring the healthy growth and development of infants and young children, as a foundation for their future success. Grant awards are made in the city of Boston and"|"1500000.0000"|"275000.0000"|"contiguous communities, as well as to organizations in which the Cabot family has philanthropic interest. Applications to the Trust are accepted twice per year for review by the trustees. Grant applications are reviewed at trustee meetings in May and November. Deadlines for grant applications are February 1 and September 1. If those dates fall on a weekend or holiday, applications are due the next business day by postmark or email. Nonprofit organizations with 501(c)(3) status are eligible for support. The Cabot Family Charitable Trust does not support sectarian programs of religious institutions, fraternal organizations, event sponsorships or matching gift programs. The Trust does not make awards to individuals. Support for summer camp programs is channeled through the Summer Fund sponsored by Associated Grant Makers. The Cabot Family Charitable Trust Annual Report lists recent grant awards at www.cabwel.com."|""

"02-6092657"|"STOKES SCHOLARSHIP TRUST"|"1267290"|""|""|""|""|""|""|""|""|"Stokes Scholarship Application"|"JULY 1"|"1. A Committee, consisting of both town and school volunteers, will act as the duly authorized agent in all procedural matters such as approval and designation of scholarship recipients. 2. Information about the scholarship will be disseminated to all seniors through all possible channels by the guidance office of the high school. 3. Students will complete an application for the scholarship and submit it to Fleet Bank - NH through a screening committee. 4. The screening committee shall gather"|"43000.0000"|""|"information on the scholarship, leadership, character, and high moral qualities from each of the perspective candidates. The Committee shall interview, or review letters of recommendation from, teachers, counselors and others as necessary to determine prospective candidates. Each candidate shall be interviewed by the screening committee. 5. Upon the collection of such data, the candidates shall be listed in rank order by the Committee beginning with the most qualified and proceeding to least qualified. This completed list shall be submitted by June 1 annually. 6. In determining prospective candidates the Committee shall keep in mind the trust provision which gives consideration to those students who attend a school or program for nursing training. 7. The recommendations shall be reviewed by the Committee and a final list of recipients, and the college, university, vocational school, or two year college the recipient will attend shall be forwarded by the committee to the Trustee, Fleet Bank - NH, 650 Elm Street, Manchester, New Hampshire by July 1 annually. 8. The Trustee will notify the appropriate education institution of the scholarship award and the conditions of payment. In the event a student decides to forego a semester in whole or part, the educational system will notify the Trustee as soon as possible. The Trustee shall notify the committee of any adjustments."|""

"04-6118945"|"H GRAFTON JR B/0 MEM FD U/M"|"1267539"|""|"JOHN M DOLAN"|"28 STATE ST"|"BOSTON"|"MA"|"USA"|""|""|"Bank of America serves as trustee or co-trustee of numerous trusts and foundations. As steward of these charitable funds, the bank created a highly specialized group within Philanthropic Management that provides grantmaking solutions designed to meet the grantmaking and fiduciary needs of these foundations and trusts. This team ensures that meaningful grants are awarded in accordance with the philanthropic mission of each foundation. www.bankofamerica.com/grantmakingsolutions Working either with"|"SEPTEMBER 15"|"DUXBURY, MA ONLY. GENERAL CHARITABLE PURPOSES."|"34400.0000"|""|"an internal distribution committee or in conjunction with a co-trustee, family member, or external advisor, the Grantmaking team carefully evaluates grant proposals and proactively seeks opportunities to make grants that promote the philanthropic goals of every trust we hold, whatever its size or mission. In the foundations where the donor has granted us broad discretion, we have focused our grantmaking in order to have an impact on some of the most compelling needs in our community. To that end, our philanthropic efforts focus on providing access to education, health care and human service programs that target underserved populations. Where appropriate, we encourage requests for general operating support to help build capacity and strengthen the non-profits we serve. Program requests are also considered. The majority of grants awarded are for one year, however, we will occasionally consider strategic requests for multi-year support."|""

IN ADDITION, THE FUND WAS ESTABLISHED TO SERVE AS A SOURCE OF ASSISTANCE FOR PATIENTS AND STUDENTS WITH SPECIAL NEEDS TO IMPROVE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE. THE FUND SUPPORTS MEDICAL INSTITUTIONS, SCHOOLS AND UNIVERSITIES, PROVIDING FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH, SCHOLARSHIPS AND PATIENT CARE. WHILE THE FUND HAS A SPECIAL INTEREST IN ORTHOPAEDICS, PROPOSALS INVOLVING OTHER MEDICAL SPECIALTIES AND ALL AREAS OF EDUCATION ARE CONSIDERED. ADDITIONALLY, THE FUND ASSISTS NEEDY PATIENTS WITH CATASTROPHIC MEDICAL INJURIES AND CONDITIONS THAT REQUIRE ACCESS TO QUALITY MEDICAL AND REHABILITATION SERVICES. ALL PATIENT CARE GRANTS ARE CHANNELED THROUGH THE TREATING PHYSICIAN OR INSTITUTION AND ARE NOT DISBURSED DIRECTLY TO AN INDIVIDUAL PATIENT. WHILE THE FOUNDATION IS NATIONAL IN SCOPE, THE PRIMARY SERVICE AREAS ARE NEW JERSEY AND FLORIDA."|""

The foundation generally limits its grant awards offered through competitive RFPs to 501(c)(3) tax-exempt charitable organizations, educational institutions, governmental entities or other public, non-profit entities. Private foundations, individuals, fiscal sponsorships and organizations with pending non-profit status"|"3846053.0000"|"1046666.0000"|"assistance calls. In addition, all open competitive grants rounds were submitted via online application forms. The MeHAF Board approved a new strategic plan two years ago, in April 2011. Calendar year 2012 represents the first full year in which some of the new strategic priorities were implemented and others entered concentrated planning for implementation in 2013. The four strategic priority areas for 2011-2016 are listed on the MeHAF website and below, with asterisks indicating the priories within which new initiatives were still under development for roll-out in 2013. Advancing Health System Reform Promoting Patient-Centered Care Improving Access to Quality Care Achieving Better Health in Communities One notable aspect of grantmaking in 2012 is that relatively few Requests for Proposals (RFPs) were released since a high proportion of funds were awarded as renewals or extensions of existing grants as well as through the foundation-initiated (invited) grant process. Four competitive RFPs were released and three sets of renewal grants were completed. A total of 83 grants and contracts were approved. MeHAF continues to use the model of convening grantees for regular meetings to share information and for ""learning communities"" at which experts share relevant information and research. Feedback from grantees indicates that this is viewed as helpful to their work and staff views this as among the most important things that MeHAF can do to ensure grantees success."|""

The poultry industry has rendered great service to the health and well-being of people all over the world. It has led the way in utilizing new knowledge and technology to greatly improve the availability and efficiency of production of animal protein foods for human diets. The Foundation wishes to encourage continued progress in technology and efficiency of production of poultry products. "04-6049261"|"THE JAFFE FOUNDATION"|"1308525"|""|"HOLLY SEAGRAVE"|"PO BOX 307"|"STOCKBRIDGE"|"MA"|"USA"|"01262"|""|"Introduction The Jaffe Foundation was founded in 1962 by Meyer Jaffe on the basis of a strong commitment to moral and ethical principles of Judaism and concern for the Jewish people throughout the world Over the ensuing twenty-five years, the interest in Jewish causes has continued and the concerns have gone beyond to include other minorities At the time of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Foundation, the Board has taken upon itself the task of redefining its goals so that there is a clear"|""|""|"105963.0000"|""|"sense of mission for the present trustees of the Board and for those that will follow in their place The intent of this task of redefinition is to build on the original purpose of its founder and on the main thrust of the Foundation's grant support during the past twenty-five years It is the belief of the Board that the broad statement below leaves sufficient room for carrying on effectively the charitable activities of the Foundation, and it is its intent that neither this board or its successors go beyond it Mission and Goals The Jaffe Foundation is dedicated to the support of disadvantaged peoples in the United States and other parts of the world In pursuing these goals, it focuse its support mainly in the areas of health, education, and the arts In addition, it is committed to the survival of the Jewish people as a cultural unity and is interested in encouraging the contribution of the Jewish people to society at large. The Foundation will consider proposals in support of a institutions for the performing arts and the fine arts b health care institutions, particularly those that emphasize preventive care c educational institutions where these institutions reach out to the community at large We will also consider proposals from organizations concerned with human rights The Foundation pursues its mission by contributing to non-profit organizations and institutions, which develop programs consistent with the above stated goals"|""

How do I submit an application?"|"December 30, 2013"|"1. What are your deadlines for receipt of proposals? Proposals are considered semi-annually. Deadline for submission are June 30 and December 30 2. Does the Foundation make grants to individuals or private foundations? No, the Foundation does not make grants to individuals or organizations classified as a private foundation. The Foundation only makes grants to organizations as described in Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. 3. What is the average size and duration of grants awarded?"|"190000.0000"|"0.0000"|"Grants are awarded semi-annually and are one-time cash awards of varying amounts, generally less than $25,000 00. 4. How many grants do you award each year? In 2007, EBK awarded 20 one-time grants 5. What are the chances that my proposal will receive support? The Foundation receives a large number of applications each year and funds those that support the goals and objectives of its patron, Esther B. Kahn, and will make a significant difference with lasting tangible results 6. Do you have formal application forms? Yes, the Foundation has implemented a two-stage application process to review proposals. Please review ""Application Instructions"" for additional details. 7. How long does it take for a proposal to be approved? The Trustees meet semi-annually, generally in February and August. All applicants will be notified of the Trustee's decision withim 10 business days after the meeting. 8. How do I submit an application? There is a two-stage application process to review proposals; a preliminary application and final application (by invitation only). Please review ""Application Instructions"" for additional details."|""

It shall be the policy of the Hubbard Farms Charitable Foundation to not utilize principal to fund contributions unless unusual circumstances exist, with all such exceptions to be voted upon by the Trustees; and in any one year such exception shall not exceed 5% of the principal balance. 2. The Foundation recognizes the special need to support those programs and institutions which strive to improve and enrich the quality of life in areas where Hubbard Farms, Inc. employees make their homes."|"55700.0000"|""|"3. The Foundation will provide support in the above areas to organizations serving these communities for purposes of education, health services, youth activities, recreation and community social welfare where our Trustees determine such support contributes to improvement of these desirable services. Efforts shall be made to implement aid for minority or disadvantaged groups which may be located in these areas. 4. The poultry industry has rendered great service to the health and well-being of people all over the world. It has led the way in utilizing new knowledge and technology to greatly improve the availability and efficiency of production of animal protein foods for human diets. The Foundation wishes to encourage continued progress in technology and efficiency of production of poultry products. For this purpose, sholar-ships will be made available to support needy and capable students in their pursuit of advanced sclentific knowledge in the fields of poultry science, genetics and other life science disciplines at universities that our Trustees consider leaders in these fields of knowledge. 5. The Foundation shall give special consideration to the support of research, education and youth activities related to the fields of activity in which Hubbard Farms, Inc. engages. 6. Major national or broad area drives to raise funds for popular causes are normally not appropriate for Foundation contributions."|""

A Committee, consisting of both town and school volunteers, will act as the duly authorized agent in all procedural matters such as apporval and designation of scholarship recipients. 2. Information about the scholarship will be disseminated to all seniors through all possible channels by the guidance office of the high school. 3. Students will complete an application for the scholarship and submit it to Fleet Bank - NH through a screening committee. 4. The screening committee shall gather"|"65000.0000"|""|"information on the scholarship, leadership, character, and high moral qualities from each of the perspective candidates. The Committee ahall interview, or review letters of recommendation from, teachers, counselors and others as necessary to determtine prospective candidates. Each candidate shall be interviewed by the screening committee. 5. Upon the collection of such data, the candidates shall be listed in rank order by the Committee beginning with the most qualifled and proceeding to least qualified. This completed list shall be submitted by June 1 annually. 6. In determining prospective candidates the Committee shall keep in mind the trust provision which gives consideration to those students who attend a school or program for nursing training. 7. The recommendations shall be reviewed by the Committee and a final list of recipienta, and the college, university, vocational school, or two year college the recipient will attend shall be forwarded by the committee to the Trustee, Fleet Bank - NH, 650 Elm Street, Manchester, New Hampshire by Jule 1 anmially. 8. The Trustee will notify the appropriate education institution of the scholarship award and the conditions of payment. Scholarships are awarded on the basis of overall academic excellence, leadership qualities and financial need. 2014 application form is available online. Mentoring Program The Tramuto"|"March 31, 2014 for the Scholarship program January 15 for the Special Grant Program"|"Max Scholarship $8,000"|"51867.0000"|""|"Foundations newest program provides its scholarship recipients with the opportunity to gain confidence, develop leadership skills, and build friendships through a direct mentoring relationship with one of our Advisory Board members. Guidance provided by our professional board members helps students learn to address challenges and issues that are a typical part of college life and gain the confidence they need to succeed in their studies and in life. Scholarship recipients are strongly encouraged to apply. Special Grant Program Each January, at the annual Advisory Board Meeting, special grants are awarded to two (2) organizations helping either an individual or community overcome a serious challenge. The following are organizations that have been helped by a Donato J. Tramuto Foundation grant: Ogunquit Playhouse Foundation hearing devices, Maine Special Olympics, Cambodia - The Sharing Foundation, Leukemia Society, katrina, 3 Family's, Walden Street School Foundation, Windbrush Farm, State of Maine foster Children Program, AIDS Seacoast Foundation. American Diabetes Association, The Friends Project, Frannie Peabody Center, Seacoast Hospice, Camp Sunshine, Gastro-Intestinal Research, Juvenile Diabetes Research Fund, and more. Application Deadline: January 15, 2012"|"Donato Tramuto"

THE FUND SUPPORTS MEDICAL INSTITUTIONS, SCHOOLS AND UNIVERSITIES, PROVIDING FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH, SCHOLARSHIPS AND PATIENT CARE. WHILE THE FUND HAS A SPECIAL INTEREST IN ORTHOPAEDICS, PROPOSALS INVOLVING OTHER MEDICAL SPECIALTIES AND ALL AREAS OF EDUCATION ARE CONSIDERED. ADDITIONALLY, THE FUND ASSISTS NEEDY PATIENTS WITH CATASTROPHIC MEDICAL INJURIES AND CONDITIONS THAT REQUIRE ACCESS TO QUALITY MEDICAL AND REHABILITATION SERVICES. ALL PATIENT CARE GRANTS ARE CHANNELED THROUGH THE TREATING PHYSICIAN OR INSTITUTION AND ARE NOT DISBURSED DIRECTLY TO AN INDIVIDUAL PATIENT. WHILE THE FOUNDATION IS NATIONAL IN SCOPE, THE PRIMARY SERVICE AREAS ARE NEW JERSEY AND FLORIDA."|""

"04-6131201"|"FIDELITY FOUNDATION"|"1687641"|""|"FIDELITY FOUNDATION"|""|""|""|""|""|""|"Strengthening Nonprofit Organizations The Fidelity Foundation grant program was designed to strengthen the long-term effectiveness of nonprofit institutions. The types of projects we fund, and the way in which we fund them, are specifically intended to help nonprofits build the organizational capabilities they need to better fulfill their missions and serve their constituencies. Approaching Grants as Investments We view our philanthropy as an investment - not just of financial resources, but"|""|"Restrictions Grants are not made to start-up, sectarian or civic organizations; public school systems; disease-specific associations; or individuals. Grants are not made for operating support, sponsorships, galas or benefits, scholarships, corporate memberships, or video and film projects. Organization and Project-Size Focus Grants are generally made only to organizations with operating budgets of $500,000 or more. Grants are made to fund only significant, transformative projects usually"|"24082325.0000"|"0.0000"|"also of our business skills and experience. In considering each proposal, we apply the fundamentals of investing: We carefully examine each aspect of an organization's project idea, management team and financial situation before committing our resources, in order to ensure that a grant can achieve tanglible results. Leveraging Resources We seek to leverage the Foundation's resources wherever possible. Often we do this by offering challenge grants that encourage nonprofits to seek and secure other funding partners. We also help match grants given by other national foundations. We draw on our own business experience by working with grantees to develop performance measures that help determine whether a grant accomplished its intended purpose. As we gain information from projects we've funded, we use it to help inform us on future projects in similar fields. We also utilize our contacts to put present grantees in touch with former grantees that have faced similar issues. Commitment to Excellence and Innovation The Foundation's grant program seeks to reflect Fidelity Investments' commitment to quality and continuous improvements. We especially look for projects representing creative and innovative means of advancing an organization or nonprofit sector and strive to remain flexible and opportunistic through a competitive selection process., budgeted at $50,000 or more."|""
